column1: The city of Lompoc (Route 135 and Route 1 from Santa Maria) sits prettily among the fields of flowers that have made it the “Flower-Growing Capital of the World.” [SEP] On the edge of town is La Purísima Mission, founded in 1787 and rebuilt in 1813 after an earthquake. [SEP] It is the most extensively and authentically restored of California’s 21 Franciscan missions, and the old pink-and-white adobe walls provide a haven of peace amid the former living and working quarters of missionaries, soldiers, and Native Americans. [SEP] The garden is full of olive and mulberry trees, and livestock such as burros, turkeys, and four-horned churro sheep all contribute to the 1820s atmosphere. [SEP] When you get to Santa Barbara you know for sure that you’ve
column3: in Southern California. [SEP] Its palm-fringed streets, red-tile pavements, and low-rise Spanish Revival buildings spread up the hillsides from the beautiful beach, oozing sun-tanned health and the scent of money. [SEP] It’s a favorite weekend retreat for many of Los Angeles’ wealthier residents. [SEP] On State Street, which runs from the beach up through the center of town, you’ll find a thriving downtown filled with stores, theaters, and restaurants. [SEP] In particular, take a peek at the Arlington Theater; the inside was designed to mimic a Spanish-style courtyard at dusk, including a star-filled sky. column1: The Kwakiutl For the relative opulence of their way of life, the Kwakiutl of British Columbia’s Pacific coast on and around Vancouver Island count among the aristocrats of Canadian native peoples. [SEP] For centuries, they have harvested an abundance of fish from the ocean and rivers — not just salmon but halibut, herring, mussels, and clams. [SEP] From the forests they have hewed red cedar planks for handsomely crafted houses and 22-m (65-ft) canoes to negotiate the coastal waters. [SEP] Before European textiles
column3: on the scene, the Kwakiutl pounded cedar bark until it was supple and soft enough to weave into capes, skirts, and blankets. [SEP] The mild climate and generally easy living have given them the leisure to develop artistic talents less apparent among native peoples and Inuit facing harsher conditions. [SEP] Elaborate decoration has gone into fashioning the simplest everyday objects — clothing, baskets, storage boxes, even fishhooks. [SEP] Carpentry is the most valued of Kwakiutl skills, and is spectacularly displayed in their totem poles. [SEP] But this is not an ancient art form. column1: St. John’s Local folklore insists that the name (not to be confused with Saint John, New Brunswick) comes from the saint’s day of John the Baptist, June 24, when John Cabot
column3: here in 1497. [SEP] Newfoundland’s capital and largest city retains the simple allure of the fishing port it has always been, and the picturesque harbor is the place to begin. [SEP] In the 19th century the town burned down five times, but it still stubbornly builds wooden houses overlooking the waterfront. [SEP] Their brightly painted walls add a welcome touch of color to the gaunt grey trawlers in the docks — from Britain, of course, but also Russia and even Japan. [SEP] Parallel to the harbor, you’ll find on Gower Street the prettiest Victorian houses, painted burgundy, lemon, burnt sienna, dove grey, and white.

[SEP] Indian hunters used to dry their buffalo meat and stretch the hides by the creek, and left the bones in a heap. [SEP] The town was known as Pile of Bones until they were ground up for fertilizer. [SEP] Today, you’ll find the buffalo, along with other regional wildlife, prehistoric and present-day, in the Museum of Natural History, on Albert Street. [SEP] The museum is south of the city center in the very pretty Wascana Park, one of the few places in southern Saskatchewan where you’ll see any trees. [SEP] The original Canarians came to be called Guanches, meaning in the native tongue “man.” [SEP] Strictly speaking, this name applies only to the original inhabitants of Tenerife. column3: in the islands around the 1st or 2nd century b.c., probably from North Africa. [SEP] Ethnographers link them with the Cro-Magnon and Proto-Mediterranean race. [SEP] They were tall, light-skinned, often blue-eyed and blond-haired. [SEP] You can see their remains in the meticulous collection of the Museo Canario in Las Palmas on Gran Canaria. column1: The Maya These people’s ancestors
column3: in Central America many thousands of years ago. [SEP] Small bands of Asiatic hunters migrated across the Bering Strait land bridge before 12,000 b.c. and gradually spread southwards through the Americas. [SEP] During the Archaic period (after 5,200 b.c.), these people settled in what is now modern Mexico. [SEP] They developed a primitive agriculture, domesticating cattle and cultivating corn, beans, chili peppers, and squash (a pumpkin-like vegetable) in burned clearings in the jungle. [SEP] Over time, a society developed that was so successful they could devote time to activities other than simple food cultivation. [SEP] These people, known as the Olmec, are considered to be the first Mesoamerican culture, the one from which all others evolved. [SEP] They developed a calendar based on a 52

column1: l caste of high priests. [SEP] Grain and animals were used, but the gods came to demand more, and a cult of human sacrifice grew. [SEP] The Maya went out on raiding parties, taking hostages from the surrounding lands to use in their bloody ceremonies. [SEP] The murals and reliefs at Mayan cities tell gory tales of beheading and the tearing out of human hearts to appease the lords of the underworld. [SEP] Archaeologists dredging the Sacred Cenote of Chichén Itzá have recovered dozens of human skeletons, thought to be the remains of victims sacrificed to the rain god. [SEP] Mayan civilization in the northern Yucatán reached its peak around a.d. 900–1200. [SEP] For reasons still unknown — perhaps civil war, drought, or disease — the great cities were abandoned. [SEP] By the time the Spaniards
column3: in the early 16th century the jungle was reclaiming the pyramids; the richly painted murals of warriors, Mayan lords, animals, and gods were already crumbling and dissolving in the warm rain. [SEP] The priest caste seemed to have vanished, along with their knowledge. [SEP] The only people the Spanish found were farmers. [SEP] In the Wake of Cortés

column1: Isla Mujeres (Island of the Women) lies only 8 km (5 miles) offshore from Cancún; the 40-minute ferry ride transports you from an ultra-modern atmosphere to an environment in which time moves more slowly. [SEP] Several companies offer one-day sailing trips to Isla Mujeres, often including lunch and snorkeling; they depart from Playa Linda and Pier Tortugas in the Hotel Zone. [SEP] Isla Mujeres now has a population of around 15,000. [SEP] In past centuries, however, it was the haunt of Caribbean pirates, being far from the clutches of colonial overlords in Havana, San Juan in Puerto Rico, and Panama City, the nearest colonial outposts. [SEP] The earliest recorded visitors
column3: in 1517, when Spanish explorer Francisco Hernández de Córdoba landed to discover a number of small temples built for the goddess of fertility Ix chel. [SEP] It was he who named the island. [SEP] Mujeres is only 8 km (5 miles) in length, less than a kilometer (1⁄2 mile) at its widest point, and split by inland lakes and bays. [SEP] One main road forms an ellipse, following the shape of the coastline. [SEP] Most ferries deposit you at the very northern tip of the island, on the main pier of the only town on Mujeres. [SEP] Craft shops and bars crowd onto the sidewalks and sandy streets. [SEP] The place bustles, especially when the ferries arrive. [SEP] As afternoon turns to evening and the day-trippers head back to Cancún, Isla Mujeres takes on a much quieter character. [SEP] The island has ma

[SEP] Then in the third century, in the era of the Three Kingdoms, it was christened “Jianye.” [SEP] Under that or similar titles it served as the capital of six southern dynasties. [SEP] The Ming emperors made it the national capital, but this was soon moved north to Beijing in the 15th century. [SEP] In the 20th century a series of dramas overtook Nanjing and gave it new prominence. [SEP] It was here that Dr. Sun Yat-sen was elected president of the republic. [SEP] Chiang Kai-shek made it his capital until the advance of Japanese invasion forces induced him to head west. [SEP] When the Japanese troops finally
column3: here in 1937, the “Rape of Nanking” was added to the catalogue of war’s atrocities. [SEP] A monument (Datusha Jinianguan) just outside the old city wall commemorates the victims; around 100,000 died in the first four days alone. [SEP] The Nationalists regained the battered city after the Japanese surrender in 1945. [SEP] The Communist army crossed the Yangzi (which the Chinese people call Changjiang, or “Long River”) in April 1949, bringing the new order to the old capital. [SEP] The Yangzi River Bridge (Nanjing Changjiang Daqiao) is an extraordinary engineering achievement. [SEP] Only a few bridges span the entire river, and this is the longest: at 1,577 m over water, it is a little less than a mile. column1: The French Quarter West of the riverside and old Chinese section is a landmark of modern history: the low brick building at 76 Xingyelu, where the Chinese Communist Party was founded in July 1921. [SEP] This was in the French concession, and when the French police learned of the clandestine meeting, they raided the two-story corner house. [SEP] But they
column3: too late to find the 12 conspirators, including Mao Zedong. [SEP] The Communist founding fathers continued their congress aboard a hired excursion boat on a lake. [SEP] The house is today a museum with documents and displays. [SEP] Today, much of the finest European architecture in Shanghai is most visible in and around the French Quarter. [SEP] Art-Deco and Tudor villas, neo-Gothic offices, and large elegant mansions line many of the small streets. [SEP] The modern Garden Hotel (58 Maominglu) preserves the original lobby area of the Cercle Sportif Français from the 1920s. [SEP] The Shanghai Arts and Crafts Research Institute is housed in a wonderful old French mansion (79 Fenyanglu) and allows visitors to view artisans at work on embroidery, paper cutting, and other crafts.

column1: wonder the Shaolin Monastery has become one of China’s more popular tourist attractions. [SEP] Shaolin now provides movie sets for film crews as well as schools for domestic and foreign classes in self-defense. [SEP] As an excursion, it is close to Zhengzhou (80 km/50 miles to the east) and Luoyang (70 km/43 miles west). [SEP] You don’t have to be a kung fu practitioner to enjoy Shaolin. [SEP] While crowded and commercialized, Shaolin is still one of China’s most interesting historical and religious monuments, dating back to the end of the fifth century a.d. In 625 it was expanded by a Tang Dynasty emperor in gratitude for wartime services rendered by the Shaolin monks, who used their fighting skills to send off some usurpers. [SEP] In the early sixth century, a monk from India named Da Mo
column3: at Shaolin, where he founded Chan Buddhism. [SEP] Da Mo, who was probably a legendary rather than actual figure, is also heralded as the founder of kung fu (wushu), a system of hand-to-hand combat that was later modified to produce the immensely popular form of exercise that millions practice every morning throughout China — taiqi (tai chi), sometimes called “shadow boxing” in the West. [SEP] The Shaolin monks do seem to have been well-versed in self-defense over the centuries. [SEP] In the 16th century they were called upon to rid China’s coast of Japanese pirates. [SEP] In 1928, when warlords carved up sections of the faltering Chinese Republic, one general laid siege to the monastery and set it ablaze.

column1: Nanchang, Jiangxi Province. [SEP] Founded in the Han Dynasty, Nanchang is the provincial capital and main industrial center of the subtropical Jiangxi Province. [SEP] In 1927 it was the setting for the first Communist-led armed uprising against the Nationalist forces. [SEP] A number of relics of Zhou Enlai and other leaders of the Nanchang Uprising have been preserved in the city’s museum, which is devoted to the insurrection. [SEP] Ningbo (Ningpo), Zhejiang Province. [SEP] Situated down the coast from Shanghai, this port town has a long history of overseas connections. [SEP] First it was involved in trade with Japan. [SEP] Then the Portuguese
column3: and settled here. [SEP] Finally, a British consulate was established in the town after the end of the Opium Wars. [SEP] The sights include a thousand-year-old wooden temple and a Ming Dynasty library in a pretty garden. [SEP] Qufu (Chufu), Shandong Province. [SEP] The birthplace of Confucius has been turned into an architectural ensemble on the scale of the Forbidden City in Beijing. [SEP] The memorial temple was begun in 478 b.c., the year after the philosopher’s death, and improvements and expansions went on for another 2,000 years. [SEP] The compound itself contains ceremonial gateways, palaces, pavilions, and shrines. [SEP] The tombs of Confucius and most of his descendants are set among ancient pines and cypress to the north of the town.

column1: The Phoenicians ventured across the Mediterranean from present-day Lebanon, reaching Spain by about 1100 b.c. They founded many trading settlements in the “remote” or “hidden land” they named Span or Spania. [SEP] The Costa Blanca was soon dotted with such Phoenician towns as Elche and Játiva. [SEP] After about 650 b.c., Greek traders
column3: on the coast to compete for Spain’s rich mineral deposits and fertile land. [SEP] The influence of Greece was short-lived, although the olive and the grape, Greek legacies, are cultivated in the region. [SEP] The Carthaginians, a people related to the Phoenicians, came from North Africa and subsequently took over much of southern Spain, beginning with Cádiz in 501 b.c. The town had sought help from the Carthaginian army in its war against local tribes, and the “invited guest” decided to stay. [SEP] The main centre of Carthaginian power in Spain was located on the Costa Blanca: Carthago Nova, now Cartagena, followed in prominence by Alicante.

column1: Moorish Domination In a.d. 711, the Arab chief Tariq landed at Gibraltar with 12,000 Berber troops. [SEP] Thus began an 800-year epoch of Christian opposition to the newly
column3: Muslims. [SEP] The Moors—the name commonly given to all Muslims in Spain—carried all before them. [SEP] Within ten years their green-crescent standard flew over most of Spain. [SEP] Kartajanah, Mursiyah, and Xativa are still known by their Moorish names. [SEP] The Moors were relatively tolerant rulers who taxed non-believers rather than trying to convert them. [SEP] They introduced the manufacture of paper, which is carried on today in Játiva. [SEP] They laid out a system of irrigation still in use in the Guadalest Valley and filled the huertas (orchards) of the Costa Blanca with oranges, peaches, and pomegranates. [SEP] Rice, cotton, and sugar cane were also first cultivated on Spanish soil by the Moors.

column1: The Golden Age Spain’s golden century began under the “Catholic Monarchs,” a title conferred by Pope Alexander VI on Ferdinand II and Isabella, who united the country under the Christian kingdoms of Aragon and Castile after the fall of Granada in 1492. [SEP] That same eventful year, Columbus, seeking a western route to the East on behalf of the Catholic Monarchs,
column3: in the Americas. [SEP] And Ferdinand and Isabella consolidated Christian rule by decreeing that all Jews—the banking and business experts—must adopt Catholicism or be exiled. [SEP] The Moors —the source of cheap labour and vital agricultural know-how—were given the same alternative in 1502. [SEP] The Segura Valley was the last part of Spain to be inhabited by Muslims, who abandoned their fortresses there in 1505. [SEP] As the Inquisition established its reign of terror to stamp out heresy, converted Jews, conversos, and Muslims, moriscos, were looked upon with suspicion, and many left the country or were condemned to death. [SEP] Agricultural productivity was to suffer considerably after the official expulsion of the moriscos in 1609.

column1: The southern part of Spain is at a geographical crossroads: It is the gateway between the Mediterranean and the Atlantic, and the crossing point between Africa and Europe. [SEP] The strategic importance of its location has given rise to a long and turbulent history. [SEP] The earliest evidence of human occupation is provided by the Paleolithic cave paintings, some 25,000 years old, in the Cueva de la Pileta. [SEP] Neolithic peoples
column3: on the scene in the fourth millennium b.c., leaving behind signs of early attempts at agriculture and fragments of their pottery. [SEP] Tribes of Iberians from North Africa crossed over into Spain around 3000 b.c., and initiated Spain’s first experiments in architecture; Spain’s oldest structure stands near Antequera, a dolmen burial chamber known as the Cueva de Romeral. [SEP] After 900 b.c., wandering bands of Celts entered the peninsula from northern Europe, and brought to the area their knowledge of bronze and iron work. [SEP] As they moved farther south, the Celts merged with the Iberians, and began to build walled villages along the coast. [SEP] Traders and Colonizers

column1: The capital of Andalucía, Sevilla is the most Spanish of Spanish cities. [SEP] One of the most beautiful cities in the world, it has a sensual, spiritual, and romantic ambience. [SEP] It was already a thriving riverside settlement when Julius Caesar
column3: in 45 b.c., and under the Romans, it developed into a major town. [SEP] In fact, two Roman emperors, Hadrian and Trajan, were born in nearby Itálica. [SEP] Subsequently, Sevilla became the capital of the Visigothic kingdom and then of a Moorish taifa, before falling to King Ferdinand III in 1248. [SEP] A monopoly of trade with the New World brought the city to its peak during the Golden Age. [SEP] “Madrid is the capital of Spain,” the saying went, “but Sevilla is the capital of the world.” [SEP] The two most prominent monuments in the city are located around the Plaza del Triunfo. [SEP] When Roman power split in two, the eastern Byzantine Empire inherited the island (though its hold on islands in the south of its dominion were, in reality, nominal). [SEP] This did not satisfy the people and the prince was forced to resign only a few years later under threat of revolt and the demand for union with Greece. [SEP] It was only in 1913, under the leadership of Elefthérios Venizélos, a native Cretan, that the longed-for énosis (union) was achieved. [SEP] Though unscathed by World War I, Crete saw major changes in the mid 1920s. [SEP] The Atatürk revolution, which announced a new Turkish Republic, brought massive upheaval through the area with a forced population exchange between Greece and Turkey beginning in 1923. [SEP] Thousands of Turks were evacuated, and thousands of Greek refugees from Asia Minor

[SEP] The new science of archaeology was also developing, and excavations of Minoan palaces brought a new prosperity as the 20th-century phenomenon of tourism grew. [SEP] War and Peace

column1: A block north of the Plaza Mayor is the Museo Nacional de la Lucha Contra Bandidos (National Museum of the Struggle against the Bandits), housed in a former convent. [SEP] The bandits in question were counter-revolutionary rebels who hid in the Escambray mountains during the 1960s. [SEP] The stupendous 360-degree view from the yellow belltower (a landmark) is the big draw. [SEP] A block south of Plaza Mayor on Calle Simón Bolivar stands the grand Palacio Cantero, built in 1830. [SEP] Painted pillars, scrolls, shells, pediments, and drapes embellish the interior, eclipsing the historical artifacts and old furniture that now form the Museo Municipal de Historia. [SEP] The all-seeing eyes here seem genuinely penetrating, almost glowering above the whitewashed dome. [SEP] The question mark “nose” is actually the Nepali numeral one, meaning the only way to enlightenment is by following the rules of conduct laid down by the Buddha. [SEP] Boudhanath has attracted Tibetan monks and pilgrims for centuries, and over the years a Tibetan and Sherpa community has grown in this area. [SEP] Where Swayambhunath is cluttered with monuments in different styles, at Boudhanath there are no other temples to distract pilgrims. [SEP] There are, however, dozens of shops specializing in Tibetan antiques and other Tibetan souvenirs. [SEP] Pilgrims coming from Tibet, as well as local refugees, supply the shops that ring the stupa with the city’s best selection of Tibetan antiques. [SEP] There are also shops filled with bronze Buddhist statuary, silver ornaments, prayer wheels, and brass “singing bowls.”

column1: Meanwhile, a European with an eye for chance had ingratiated his way into the French court at Versailles. [SEP] John Law, a Scotsman, financier, and high-rolling gambler, on the run from England after a fatal duel, saw the possibility of promoting this distant marshland as a paradise. [SEP] Luckily for New Orleans, his scheme was a remarkable success. [SEP] Law brokered a deal with the French government, giving him a 25-year charter to develop the Louisiana Territory. [SEP] All he needed were investors and settlers, whom he lured with a campaign of propaganda. [SEP] On posters Law distributed in France, New Orleans was pictured as a prosperous seaport. [SEP] When Law’s clients
column3: after months at sea, the truth of the Mississippi Bubble was plain. [SEP] The only housing available was huts or tents, and the roads were generally quagmires. [SEP] But there was nowhere else to go, so the pioneers were forced to pitch in and try to survive. [SEP] John Law’s promotional activities weren’t confined to the French. [SEP] He signed up some 10,000 Germans, mostly Rhinelanders, to share the “golden future” in Louisiana. [SEP] Today, west of New Orleans along what is called the German Coast, you can see towns with names like Hahnville, Kraemer, and Des Allemands. [SEP] The Arc de Triomphe was conceived by Napoléon I as a tribute to his armies, and bears the names of hundreds of his marshals and generals, and dozens of victories. [SEP] No defeats are recorded, naturally, although a few of the victories are debatable. [SEP] Napoléon himself only ever saw a wood and canvas model: the arch was completed during the 1830s. [SEP] It soon became the focus for state occasions, such as the return of the ex-emperor’s own remains from St. Helena in 1840 and the funeral of Victor Hugo in 1885. [SEP] In 1920, the Unknown Soldier of World War I was buried at the arch; three years later the eternal flame was lit. [SEP] When Adolf Hitler
column3: in Paris as a conqueror in 1940, the Arc de Triomphe was the first place he wanted to see. [SEP] And at the Liberation, this was the spot where General de Gaulle commenced his triumphal march down the Champs-Elysées. [SEP] Avenue Foch, leading away from l’Etoile to the Bois de Boulogne, is one of the most majestic of the city’s residential avenues. [SEP] It is one of the most exclusive, too, though somewhat democratized these days by the groups of boules players on its graveled side paths. [SEP] Avenue de la Grande-Armée points straight to Neuilly and the towers of La Défense with the Grande Arche behind.

column1: Foundations of the Polish State The region that would become Poland, a great plain sandwiched between the Vistula and Odra rivers, has been inhabited since the Stone Age by migratory tribal peoples — among them Celts, Balts, Huns, Slavs and Mongols. [SEP] Tribal culture reigned, untouched by the more sophisticated civilization of the Roman Empire. [SEP] Slavic tribes
column3: by the eighth century a.d. and put down roots; the •lezanie, Mazowszanie, Pomorzanie and Wislanie peoples inhabited much of the territory. [SEP] The Polonian tribe, which settled the area that today is western Poland around Poznan, provided the foundations for the development of a Polish language and nation. [SEP] Prince Mieszko, leader of the Piast dynasty that ruled the Polonians, undertook the bold step to unify the Polanie (literally, “people of the fields”) and neighboring tribes.
